value.title: Retirement: Remove dependency on these Azure ML SDKs before June 30, 2026
value.description:
On June 30, 2026, AzureML SDK V1 will reach end of life. The following SDKs which work in tandem with the AzureML SDK V1 will also be retired.  

  • azureml-train-core  

  • azureml-pipeline  

  • azureml-pipeline-core  

  • azureml-pipeline-internal  

  • azureml-pipeline-steps  

After June 30, 2026, you can continue to use these SDKs, however they will not be supported and may stop working without notice.  

Recommended action  

To ensure that you are using a supported SDK for your workloads, it is recommended to migrate to AzureML SDK V1 before 30 Jun 2026.  

Detailed guidance is documented here.

Help and support  

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, create a support case.  

Links provided herein may take you to a third-party website and are provided for convenience only. Third-party websites are subject to the third-party's terms and privacy statements.  

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

value.title: Retirement: Migrate to dedicated VM for your compute clusters
value.description:
On September 30, 2025, Low-Priority VM will reach end of life. However, you will continue to be supported on Azure Machine Learning until March 31, 2026.  

To ensure that your clusters are not automatically scaled down it is recommended to migrate to dedicated VMs before that date.  

After March 31, 2026, you'll not be able to use your clusters with low-priority VM.  

 

Required action  

To ensure you're using a supported cluster, you can recreate your low-priority VM clusters with dedicated VM before March 31, 2026.  

Detailed guidance is documented here 

Help and support  

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, create a support case.  

Links provided herein may take you to a third-party website and are provided for convenience only. Third-party websites are subject to the third-party's terms and privacy statements.  

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

value.title: Retirement: Support for Python 3.10 ends on October 1st, 2026
value.description:
On October 1, 2026 extended support for Python 3.10 will end. Your apps that are hosted on App Service will continue to run, but security updates will no longer be available, and we’ll no longer provide customer service for Python 3.10. Learn more about App Service language support. 

Required action 

To avoid potential security vulnerabilities and minimize risk for your App Service apps, follow the steps to upgrade your app to Python 3.11 before October 1, 2026.

value.title: Retirement: Windows Server 2022 on Azure Kubernetes Service enabled by Azure Arc
value.description: Announcing the  retirement of Windows Server 2022 on Azure Kubernetes Service enabled by Azure Arc in October 2026.

value.title: Retirement: Support for Node.js 20 ends on April 30, 2026 – upgrade your apps to Node.js 22
value.description:
In alignment with the end of community support, on April 30, 2026, support for Node.js 20 in Azure Functions will end. Your apps that are hosted on Functions will continue to run, but security updates and performance optimizations will no longer be available and we'll no longer provide customer support for Node.js 20.  

Required action   

To avoid potential security vulnerabilities and take advantage of the latest features, follow the steps to upgrade your Functions apps to Node.js 22 by April 30, 2026 

 

More information 

If you have a support plan and you need technical help, open the Azure portal and select the question mark icon at the top of the page.  

Learn more.

value.title: Retirement: Remove dependency on these preview features before March 31, 2026
value.description:
On March 31, 2026, the following preview features will be retired:  

  • Group multiple steps as a whole to better organize complex pipelines  

  • Compare pipeline jobs to debug failures or unexpected issues  

  • Import data into a data labelling project  

  • Use v2 data asset (uri_folder and mltable) in a data labelling project  

  • Monitor data drift between training and inference  

  • Add linked services  

  • Monitor compute resource  

After March 31, 2026, these preview features will no longer be available.  

To ensure that you do not run into an issue, it is recommended to remove dependency on these features before May 31, 2026.  

Detailed guidance is documented here.

Help and support  

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, create a support case.  

Links provided herein may take you to a third-party website and are provided for convenience only. Third-party websites are subject to the third-party's terms and privacy statements.  

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

value.title: Retirement: Azure Computer Vision – Image Analysis will be retired on September 25, 2028
value.description:
Microsoft is announcing the planned retirement of the Azure Computer Vision – Image Analysis service.   

Microsoft will provide full support for all existing Azure Computer Vision – Image Analysis customers until 9/25/2028. During this support window, customers are encouraged to begin planning and executing their transition to one of the following Azure products. Your product transition plan will depend on the specific use cases for Image Analysis. 

  • For OCR and Read capabilities, utilize Document Intelligence 

  • For Face scenarios, use the Face API 

  • For other Computer Vision scenarios, utilize the GPT model series found in the Microsoft Foundry. 

  • Azure AI is offering a new product currently in preview, Azure AI Content Understanding, that is powered by LLMs and also supports many image analysis use cases 

  • See the Azure Computer Vision – Image Analysis documentation for more information on your specific use case

value.title: Retirement: Confidential Containers preview on AKS is Closing Down
value.description:
The public preview of Confidential Containers on AKS will be shutting down.

This feature has been available in preview since 2023, and as part of our commitment to delivering secure and reliable services, we are streamlining our confidential computing offerings to focus on supported and production-ready solutions.   
   
What this means for you:  

  • Existing node pools using KataCcIsolation will continue to operate until March 2, 2026. 

  • After March 2, 2026, Confidential Container functionality will no longer be supported, and new node pools using this runtime cannot be created. 

Please refer to the Confidential Containers preview page for more details, or raise an issue in the AKS GitHub.

value.title: Retirement: The F, Fs, Fsv2, Lsv2, G, Gs, Av2, Amv2, and B series VMs are retiring in 2028
value.description:
The F, Fs, Fsv2, Lsv2, G, Gs, Av2, Amv2, and B series of Azure Virtual Machines will retire on November 15th, 2028. These VMs will no longer be able to be used or purchased after this date.   

To ensure any applications and workloads running on these VMs will be operating in the future, you need to migrate your F, Fs, Fsv2, Lsv2, G, Gs, Av2, Amv2, and B VM series workloads to a newer VM series. 

Three-year reserved instances for these VMs can no longer be purchased or renewed starting on Novermber 15th, 2025. One-year reserved VM instances for these VMs will not be available for purchased or renewal after November 15th, 2027.  

If you have a three-year reserved instance contract for these VMs, you’ll still receive your reserved instances benefit for the remainder of the contract. After that, you’ll be billed at pay-as-you-go rates. To plan for this change and avoid unexpected billing, we recommend reviewing your current reserved instance orders to identify impacted VMs and their expiration dates.   

For pricing details, please refer to the VM pricing pages and the pricing calculator. For additional support, you can create a support request by following this process here. You can also get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, open the Azure portal and select the question mark icon at the top of the page.

value.title: Retirement: Azure Custom Vision will be retired on September 25, 2028
value.description:
Microsoft is announcing the planned retirement of the Azure Custom Vision service.  

Microsoft will provide full support for all existing Azure Custom Vision customers until 9/25/2028. During this support window, customers are encouraged to begin planning and executing their transition to alternative solutions. Depending on your use case, we recommend the following paths for transition: 

  • For creating custom models for both image classification and object detection, Azure Machine Learning AutoML offers the ability to train both custom model types using classic machine learning techniques 

Microsoft is also investing in Generative AI-based solutions that increase accuracy in custom scenarios using prompt engineering and other techniques. 

  • To use generative models, you can use one of models available in the Azure AI Foundry model catalog and create your own solution for customized vision. 

  • For a managed generative solution for image classification, Azure AI Content Understanding (currently in public preview) offers the ability to create custom classification workflows. It also supports processing unstructured data of any type (image, documents, audio, video) and extract structured insights based on pre-defined or user-defined formats.  

For additional context on alternative options, see the Azure Custom Vision documentation.

value.title: Retirement: Azure AI Health Insights and related models
value.description:
As part of a strategic review of our AI portfolio, Azure AI Health Insights service and the Clinical Trials Matcher and Radiology Insights models will be retired on December 31, 2025, and will no longer be available for use or integration. 

As a result, effective December 31, 2025: 

  • All endpoints and container images for these models will be removed from the Microsoft Artifact Registry. 

  • Any deployments of the models in your own hosting environment will cease to function. 

  • Endpoints for the service and models will no longer be available via the Azure Portal. 

  • API calls to these models will no longer return results. 

If you have questions or need help planning for this transition, our Customer Service and Support (CSS) team is here for you. If you don’t currently have CSS support, you can explore support options here: [Azure Support Plans Comparison | Microsoft Azure]

value.title: Retirement: Azure Cache for Redis is retiring on September 30, 2028
value.description:
Azure Cache for Redis (Basic, Standard and Premium) will be retired on September 30, 2028 and we recommend you migrate your workloads to use Azure Managed Redis before September 30, 2028. Azure Cache for Redis instances that are not migrated by September 30, 2028 will be shut down.  
Learn more.

value.title: Retirement: Azure Cache for Redis Enterprise is retiring on March 30, 2027
value.description:
Azure Cache for Redis Enterprise and Enterprise Flash tiers is retiring on March 31, 2027 and we recommend you migrate your workloads to use Azure Managed Redis by that date. Starting April 1, 2026, users will not be able to create new instances of Azure Cache for Redis Enterprise. All remaining Azure Cache for Redis Enterprise and Enterprise Flash instances will be migrated to Azure Managed Redis automatically after April 1, 2027. 
Learn more.

value.title: Retirement: Azure Network Policy Manager (NPM) for Windows nodes on AKS to Be Retired by September 30, 2026
value.description:
On September 30, 2026, we’ll end support for Azure Network Policy Manager (NPM) on Windows nodes in AKS. To ensure your setup continues to receive support, security updates, and deployment compatibility, please explore alternative options, such as using Network Security Groups (NSGs) on the node level or open-source tools like Project Calico by that date. 

The existing experience that Azure Network Policy Manager for windows nodes offers will no longer be supported starting September 30, 2026.   

To view your impacted resources, go to this Azure Resource Graph query and click Run query.     

Help and support 

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and need technical help, please submit a support request.

value.title: Retirement: Legacy Authentication in Azure Monitor - Container Insights will be retired on September 30, 2026.
value.description:
Legacy Authentication in Azure Monitor - Container Insights will be retired on September 30, 2026.  Legacy authentication has been replaced by the more secure Managed Identity authentication method. Migrating to Managed Identity also gives customers access to newer Container Insights features like Syslog collection and High Scale mode which are available only with Managed Identity.  

Required action

Customers must migrate to the new Managed Identity authentication before September 30, 2026. Customers can migrate their clusters with a single click from the Azure portal. Azure Monitor documentation also has command line options and a bulk migration script.

Please see migration guidance here.

value.title: Azure unmanaged disks will be retired on 31 March 2026 (formerly 30 September 2025)
value.description:
In 2017, we launched Azure Managed Disks. Since then, we've been enhancing our capabilities. We will begin deprecating unmanaged disks on September 30, 2022, because Azure Managed Disks now have full capabilities of unmanaged disks and other advancements. This functionality will be completely retired on March 31, 2026 (extended from September 30, 2025). 

With managed disks, Azure manages storage accounts automatically, reducing customer maintenance burden significantly. Furthermore, managed disks provide numerous advantages over unmanaged disks such as better reliability, scalability, greater storage capacity, bursting, shared disks etc.,  

If you use unmanaged disks, you should start planning your migration now. Migrate your data from Azure unmanaged disk storage to managed disks before March 31, 2026. Page blobs will not be affected by this change.

To avoid serious service disruptions, review pricing and follow the steps to migrate your Windows or Linux virtual machines to managed disks before March 31, 2026. 

To learn more, read the documentation.  

Required action

To avoid service disruptions, review pricing and follow the steps to migrate your Windows or Linux virtual machines to managed disks before 30 September 2025.

Help and support

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, please create a support request.

value.title: Retirement: Azure Monitor SCOM Managed Instance will be retired on Sep 30, 2026
value.description:
After September 30, 2026, customers will no longer be able to access the service. Please see our retirement documentation for more details. 

Recommended action 

If your goal is to monitor on-premises workloads, please transition to Operations Manager on-premises. You would need to delete your existing SCOM MI instance and re-deploy SCOM on-premises (hosted on on-premises datacenters or in Azure) using the steps mentioned here. 

If your goal is to monitor Azure-hosted or Azure Arc-enabled workloads, please transition to Azure Monitor. You would need to delete your existing SCOM MI instance, obtain a list of rules and monitors in the SCOM MI Management Packs (MP) that you are currently using, and determine their equivalence in Azure Monitor Data Collection Rules (DCR) by creating a DCR for each SCOM MP monitor you are using and integrating that with Azure Monitor VM Insights Alerts.

value.title: Retirement: Azure Static Web Apps database connection feature
value.description:
Due to changes in underlying infrastructure, the database connections feature of Static Web Apps this feature (currently in public preview), will be deprecated effective November 30, 2025.  To avoid issues in deployments using this feature you can refactor your application to a self-hosted instance of the Data API Builder and deploy that to Azure Container Apps.   

This page provides guidance to help migrate your deployments. 

If you have a support plan and need technical help, you can open the ⁠Azure portal and select the question mark icon at the top of the page

value.title: Retirement: Azure VPN Gateway support for SSTP Protocol will be retired on March 31, 2027
value.description:
Due to its limited scalability and suboptimal performance, support for SSTP will be phased out. We strongly recommend transitioning to IKEv2 or OpenVPN, which offer significantly enhanced capabilities—including support for up to 10,000 connections and 10 Gbps aggregate throughput, depending on your gateway SKU.  

Key dates: 

  • Mar 31, 2026: Enabling SSTP protocol on VPN gateway will no longer be supported 
  • Mar 31, 2027: Existing SSTP-enabled gateways can no longer be used to establish SSTP connections. 

Required action

To avoid service disruptions, please follow the instructions to migrate to IKEv2 or OpenVPN before March 31, 2027.  

Help and support 

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A.  If you have a support plan and you need technical help, create a support request.

value.title: Retirement: General Purpose v1 (GPv1) and legacy blob storage accounts
value.description:
As part of our ongoing efforts to streamline the Azure Storage portfolio and deliver enhanced performance, scalability, and cost efficiency, we are announcing the retirement of all General purpose v1 (GPv1) storage accounts. This includes legacy blob storage and Files accounts configurations.

Key Dates

  • October 1st, 2025: Public announcement.

  • October 13th, 2026: Final retirement. All remaining GPv1 accounts will be transitioned to GPv2.

What’s Changing:

The following account types will be retired:

  • General purpose v1 (GPv1) storage accounts (all redundancy options)

  • Legacy blob storage accounts.

  • Files storage accounts hosted on GPv1.

Customers are encouraged to migrate to General Purpose v2 (GPv2) or specialized alternatives such as BlockBlobStorage or FileStorage, depending on workload requirements.


Automatic migration warning 

After October 13, 2026, all existing GPv1 accounts will be auto migrated over to a GPv2 account, which may result in higher billing costs. Your decision not to migrate an existing GPv1 account will be construed as consent for Microsoft to migrate the account on your behalf.


Resources

  • https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/storage-account-upgrade 

  • GPv1 storage account retirement overview - Azure Storage | Microsoft Learn

  • Legacy Blob Storage account retirement overview - Azure Storage | Microsoft Learn

Please Contact your Microsoft account team for support and migration assistance.

value.title: Retirement: Azure Machine Learning - Data labeling Deprecation
value.description:
On September 30, 2026, Azure Machine data labeling will be retired. Please transition to 3rd party data labeling providers by 30 September 2026. 

 
From today to September 30, 2026, you can continue to use data labelling without disruption. On September 30, 2026 workloads running data labelling will be deleted and associated application data will be lost.  


Recommended action    

To avoid service disruptions, please migrate the existing data labeling workloads to 3rd party providers. Once labeled data is generated, copy the labelled data into Azure machine learning storage account for further pre-processing or model training as required.

value.title: Retirement: Azure Network Policy Manager (NPM) for Linux nodes on AKS to Be Retired by September 30, 2028
value.description:
On September 30, 2028, we’ll end support for Azure Network Policy Manager (NPM) on Linux nodes in AKS. To avoid disruptions, migrate AKS clusters running Linux nodes from NPM to Cilium Network Policy by that date.   

   

Transitioning to Cilium Network Policy for AKS clusters using Azure CNI powered by Cilium provides significant improvements, including:  

  • Robust support for Kubernetes-native policies.  

  • Powerful extended features such as Layer 7 policy, and Fully Qualified Domain Name filtering.  

  • eBPF-based architecture for packet processing, offering better performance, scalability and security.   

  

To view your impacted resources, go to the Azure Resource Graph and click Run query.  

Help and support 

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and need technical help, please submit a support request.

value.title: Retirement: Support for Service Connector (preview) on Azure Container Apps will end on March 30th, 2026
value.description:
Support for Service Connector (preview) on Azure Container Apps will end on March 30, 2026. 

After this date, Service Connector (preview) will no longer be supported on Azure Container Apps. If you created service connections using the Azure Portal, your existing connections will remain active and unaffected. If you used the Azure CLI, SDKs, or Visual Studio, your existing connections may require updates or migration. You will no longer be able to create new service connections using Service Connector (preview) through any interface for Azure Container Apps. 

 
Required action 

If you used the Azure Portal to create service connections, no action is needed—your connections will remain active. If you used the Azure CLI, SDKs, or Visual Studio, review your connections and the related guidance here to avoid disruption.

value.title: Retirement: NVv4-series Azure Virtual Machines will be retired on September 30, 2026
value.description:
On September 30, 2026, Microsoft Azure will retire the Standard_NV4as_v4, Standard_NV4ahs_v4,
Standard_NV8as_v4, Standard_NV8ahs_v4,
Standard_NV16as_v4, Standard_NV16ahs_v4, Standard_NV32as_v4, and Standard_NV32ahs_v4 virtual machines (VMs) in the NVv4-series virtual machines (VMs).

Microsoft is recommending the Azure NVads_V710_v5-series VMs, which offer greater GPU memory bandwidth per GPU. These VMs are targeted for graphics applications, virtual desktops, and visualizations as well as small AI inference workloads.

For more information, please refer to the ⁠NVv4-series retirement page.

Note: There is a known resize operation error that occurs when migrating from the NVv4-series to the NVads_V710_v5-series. Microsoft is working on a fix that will be implemented in April 2026. In the meantime, we suggest that you follow this workaround.

How does the retirement of the NVv4-series virtual machines affect me? 

After September 30, 2026, any remaining NVv4-series virtual machines (VMs) subscriptions will be set to a deallocated state. They'll stop working and no longer incur billing charges. NVv4 will no longer be under SLA or have support included. 

1-year and 3-year RI purchases for the NVv4-series will end September 30, 2025.

Required action 

You need to resize or deallocate your NVv4-series VMs. We recommend that you change VM sizes for these workloads from the original NVv4-series VMs to the NVads_V710_v5-series VMs (or an alternative).

value.title: Retirement: Spark Native Connector for Semantic Link
value.description:
Starting October 1, 2025, the Spark native connector will be officially retired. This decision is based on internal analysis indicating low usage, high maintenance costs, and potential security vulnerabilities. To ensure continued support and improved security, we recommend transitioning to the Semantic Python SDK, which offers comparable functionality and enhanced support. 

After October 1, 2025, no major versions of the Spark native connector for Semantic Link will be released. Full retirement of the service is scheduled for October 1, 2028. The connector is compatible with Spark runtime versions up to 3.5. Support will not be available for Spark runtime version 4.0 or later. 

Recommended action 

  • Plan your migration to the Semantic Python SDK. 

  • Review your current usage of the Spark native connector across your Microsoft Fabric tenants. 

  • Contact us with any questions or for migration assistance. 

Help and support 

If you have any concerns or require support, please contact us at synapsemlpm@microsoft.com.

value.title: Azure VMware Solution AV36 Node Retirement on June 30, 2028
value.description:
Microsoft is announcing the retirement of the AV36 node type on June 30, 2028. The terms of your current AV36 Reserved Instance (RI) are not affected by this announcement. 

At this time, we recommend that you review your current AV36 RI expiration timeline and then work with your Microsoft Account Team on your next steps. To help with your upcoming transition, we will offer an AV36 1-year RI (with VCF included) until October 15, 2025 and AV36 VCF BYOL 1-year RI until 30 June 30, 2026. Additionally, existing AV36 PayGo subscriptions will run through until September 30, 2027. 

The details above only impact AV36 nodes. AVS AV36P, AV48, AV52 and AV64 remain available with AVS VCF BYOL options.  

Key dates for existing AV36 subscriptions with RIs: 

October 15, 2025: Last day to buy a 1-year RI for AV36 (with VCF included)  

June 30, 2026: Last day to buy a 1-year RI for AV36 VCF BYOL*   

June 30, 2028: Retirement of AV36 and AV36 VCF BYOL   

*AV36 VCF BYOL requires a portable VCF subscription from Broadcom 

 

AV36 PayGo subscriptions: 

Please reach out to your Microsoft Account Team for details and key dates for AV36 PayGo subscriptions. 

Required action 

Transition from your AV36 nodes to a new AVS node type before the end of your current AV36 RI term. Identify available AVS node types on the Azure Product by Region page, and visit the AVS Documentation page to learn about HCX migrations. 

Help and support:  

If you have questions, please reach out to your Microsoft Account Team.

value.title: Retirement: Entity Linking from Azure AI Language
value.description:
Microsoft is announcing the planned retirement of Entity Linking from Azure AI Language. We recommend considering a replacement solution; Named Entity Recognition from Azure AI Language also supports entity identification. 

Microsoft will provide full support for all existing Entity Linking until September 8, 2028. During this support window, customers are encouraged to begin planning and executing their transition to Named Entity Recognition or another replacement solution, depending on their workload and compliance requirements.  

Required action

  • Effective immediately, Microsoft will no longer accept new customer onboardings to Entity Linking.  
  • Make a plan to transition plan for Named Entity Recognition or another replacement solution by September 08, 2026  
  • Entity Linking will be retired on 8 September 2028, please transition off by that date.   

Help and support  

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and need technical help, open the Azure portal and select the question mark icon at the top of the page.

value.title: Retirement: The Linux Consumption hosting plan of Azure Functions will be retired on September 30, 2028. Migrate to Flex Consumption.
value.description:
The Azure Functions Linux Consumption hosting plan is being retired. Customers are advised to migrate to the Flex Consumption plan, which offers faster scaling, advanced networking, cold start mitigation, and concurrency control. To identify affected resources, check the Azure portal for App Service plans with Pricing Tier: Dynamic (Y1: 0) and Operating System: Linux. Key dates: 
  • After September 30, 2025: No new features for Linux Consumption; it will be removed from the Azure Portal, Visual Studio, and VS Code, but can still be managed via infrastructure as code and Azure CLI. 
  • After September 30, 2028: No technical support or ability to create new Linux Consumption function apps. 

Please migrate to Flex Consumption by September 30, 2028, to avoid service disruptions. Microsoft will provide migration documentation and tools throughout the transition.

value.title: Retirement: Upgrade BlobFuse v1 to latest version of Blobfuse v2
value.description: We recommend upgrading from BlobFuse v1 to BlobFuse v2,as all future enhancements and innovations related to Azure Blob Storage file system access will be focused exclusively on BlobFuse v2. Please note that support for BlobFuse v1 will be discontinued effective September 2026. Please migrate to BlobFuse v2 using the provided instructions.

value.title: Retirement: Azure App Service on Azure Arc enabled Kubernetes
value.description:
Beginning on September 30th 2025, Azure App Service on Azure Arc enabled Kubernetes will be retired, and customers will no longer be able to install the extension.

To continue to host your application workloads, we request you migrate to other solutions such as Azure Container Apps on Azure Arc enabled Kubernetes.  Azure Container Apps on Azure Arc enabled Kubernetes also allows you to take advantage of Logic Apps Hybrid for your integration workloads.

We recommend evaluating and migrating to another solution as early as possible to allow sufficient time for completion of migration.

Help and support

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, create a support request.
